abstract.text: The primary view controller for a custom keyboard app extension.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: To create a custom keyboard, first subclass the
class, then add your keyboardâ€™s user interface to the
property of your subclass. In Xcode, you can start a custom keyboard by choosing the Custom Keyboard target template.
A custom keyboard can respond to user input events in the following ways:
Add text in the form of an unattributed
object at the insertion point in the current text input object, by calling the
method on the
property. This property provides that method through its conformance to the
protocol
Delete text in a backward direction, starting at the insertion point, by calling the
method on the
property.
Switch to another keyboard in the set of user-enabled keyboards, by calling the
method.
Dismiss the keyboard, by calling the
method.
Obtain textual context around the insertion point by reading the
properties
and
. To find out if the current text input object is empty, call the
method on the
property. You can employ this textual context by considering it along with user input, to offer context-sensitive output to a document from your keyboard.
An input view controller conforms to the
protocol, allowing you to respond to changes in document content and position of the insertion point.
To present an appropriate keyboard layout, respond to the current text input objectâ€™s
property. For each keyboard type trait you support, change the contents of your primary view accordingly.
For more about creating a custom keyboard, read
in

abstract.text: A static, plain-text Unicode string object which you use when you need reference semantics or other Foundation-specific behavior.
Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
An interface that provides a source for shareable content to fulfill user requests to share current content.
A collection of methods that gives you access to the appearance proxy for a class.
A protocol that a class must adopt to allow appearance customization using the
API.
A set of methods for adapting the contents of your view controllers to size and trait changes.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.
A property that enables a custom input or keyboard accessory view to play standard keyboard input clicks.
The primary view controller for a custom keyboard app extension.
Switches to the next keyboard in the list of user-enabled keyboards.
Dismisses the custom keyboard from the screen.
Supports interaction with the list of user-enabled keyboards.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the keyboard has a dictation key.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the keyboard has full access.
The primary view for the input view controller.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the keyboard must display an input switcher key.
The primary language for a custom keyboard.
Obtains a supplementary lexicon of term pairs in a custom keyboard.
A proxy to the text input object that the custom keyboard is interacting with.
A set of methods a responder uses to implement simple text entry.
Deletes a character from the displayed text.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the text-entry object has any text.
Inserts a character into the displayed text.
Constants that specify the type of keyboard to display for a text-based view.
A read-only array of term pairs, each in a lexicon entry object, for a custom keyboard.
A read-only term pair, available within a lexicon object, for a custom keyboard.
The interface that determines whether a responder object supports paste configuration.
A set of standard methods that apps can adopt to support editing.
Methods for adding objects to your state restoration archives.
An object that provides textual context to a custom keyboard.
Textual context after the insertion point in the current text input object.
Textual context before the insertion point in the current text input object.
An intermediary between a document and the text input system.
A type that calls your code in reaction to changes in the trait environment.
A set of methods that makes the iOS interface environment available to your app.
The protocol you adopt to restore an objectâ€™s state from a user activity.
An object that manages a view hierarchy for your UIKit app.
Enable network access and write access to a shared group container.

doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKi.title: Configuring open access for a custom keyboard

abstract.text: Insert, delete, and manipulate text by using a proxy to a text input view.

doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKi.title: Handling text interactions in custom keyboards

abstract.text: A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The interface an app extension uses to respond to a request from a host app.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
